title: 103_hr2535
content: AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE PRIORITY HEALTH CARE TO VETERANS OF THE PERSIAN GULF WAR. Inpatient Care amendment to provide hospital and nursing home care for veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War. The amendment provides hospital and nursing home care for veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War, regardless of insufficient medical evidence linking the disability to the exposure. Amendments include expanding eligibility criteria and extending care beyond December 31, 1994. The amendment expands outpatient care eligibility for veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War, extending care beyond December 31, 1994. The amendments expand outpatient care eligibility for veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War, extending care beyond December 31, 1994. Medical services may not be provided for disabilities not associated with the exposure. Effective date of the amendments is August 2, 1990. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will reimburse veterans who paid for hospital care, nursing home care, or outpatient services due to exposure to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War. The reimbursement will be the amount paid by the veteran for such care. Extension of certain health care and other authorities includes eligibility for care for exposure to dioxin or ionizing radiation and eligibility for sexual trauma counseling for women veterans. Amendments extend deadlines for eligibility from December 31, 1993, to June 30, 1994, and from December 31, 1993, to December 31, 1994, respectively. The amendments extend deadlines for eligibility from December 31, 1993, to June 30, 1994, and from December 31, 1993, to December 31, 1994, for various provisions in title 38, United States Code. SEC. 3. SHARING OF RESOURCES WITH STATE HOMES. The purpose of amending Section 8151 of title 38, United States Code, is to improve care for veterans by allowing the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources. Additionally, the definition of "health-care resource" in Section 8152 now includes hospital care, medical services, and rehabilitative services. The amendment allows the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources, including specialized medical resources between Department health-care facilities and other health-care facilities. The Secretary can enter agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources, including specialized medical resources between Department health-care facilities and other health-care facilities. The agreements must obviate the need for duplicate resources or ensure that Department resources allocated for veterans' care are used effectively.
